statement.tex: %text If the length of three sides of trapezium other than the base is 10cm each, find the area of the trapezium when it is maximum. %
\\ %text Would the area $A$ of the required trapezium $PQRS$ be as given in the figure below? %
\\ %text \textbf{Right or wrong?} Given that \[ A = (x+10)\cdot\sqrt{100-x^2}\], the area (A) will have an \underline\text{extreme} value (maxima or minima) when the following is true. %
\\ %text Given that $A$ has an extreme value when $x=5$, which of the following sets of statements is true? %

reason.tex:
%text You can have \underline\text{infinite quadrilaterals} with three equal sides. But you can have \underline\text{only one trapezium} $(PS\parallel QR)$ with three sides equal. Hence, the required trapezium is a symmetrical figure as shown.
And in this trapezium, % \begin{align} h^2 + x^2 &= 10^2 \implies h = \sqrt{100-x^2} \\ \text{and }A &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot (PS + QR)\cdot h \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot (10 + (10+2x))\cdot h \\ &= (x+10)\cdot h \end{align}

\begin{align} A = (x+10)\cdot h &= (x+10)\cdot \sqrt{100-x^2} \\ \implies A^2 &= \underbrace{(x+10)^2\cdot (100-x^2)}_{\text{Easier to work with}} \end{align} %text
Now, \underline\text{when $A$ is at its highest or lowest value}, \underline\text{then so is $A^2$}.
Hence, when $A$ is at an extreme value, then %
\begin{align} \frac{d}{dx}A^2 = \frac{d}{dx}(x+10)^2\cdot (100-x^2) &= 0 \\ \text{or }\underbrace{(100-x^2)\cdot 2(x+10) - 2x\cdot (x+10)^2}_{\text{Chain Rule}} &= 0\\ \text{or }2\cdot(x+10)\cdot(-2x^2-10x+100) &= 0 \\ \text{or }-4\cdot(x+10)\cdot\underbrace{(x^2 + 5x-50)}_{= (x-5)\cdot (x+10)}&= 0 \\ \text{or }-4\cdot (x+10)^2\cdot (x-5) &= 0 \end{align}\\ %text
Which means that for $\frac{d}{dx}A^2 = 0$, $x=5,-10$. But $x\nless 0$. \underline\text{Therefore, $x=5$}. %
